definitions.definition: considered and judged by being compared with something else

examples.text: You must consider the **relative merits** of the two plans.
We need to assess the **relative importance** of each of these factors.
We need to assess the relative strengths and weaknesses of each system.

definitions.definition: referring to an earlier noun, sentence or part of a sentence

examples.text: In ‘the man who came’, ‘who’ is a **relative pronoun** and ‘who came’ is a **relative clause**.

definitions.definition: that exists or that has a particular quality only when compared with something else

examples.text: They now live **in relative comfort** *(= compared with how they lived before)*.
We won the game with **relative ease**.
Given the failure of the previous plan, this turned out to be a relative success.
**It's all relative** though, isn't it? We never had any money when I was a kid and $500 was a fortune to us.

definitions.definition: in comparison with somebody/something else; in relation to somebody/something

examples.text: the position of the sun relative to the earth
The movements of the continents relative to each other can be measured.
The company employs too many people relative to the size of its business.

definitions.definition: having a connection with somebody/something; concerning somebody/something

examples.text: He may have information relative to the case.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French relatif, -ive, from late Latin relativus ‘having reference or relation’, from the verb referre ‘carry back’, from re- ‘back’ + ferre ‘bring’.
